titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Records of the Asian/Pacific/American Institute RG.21.35
titlestmt.author: Lesley Espenship, John Bence and Lindsay Dumas. Additional accessions processed by Megan Findling and Aleksandr Gelfand.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-12-12 19:12:25 -0500.

did.abstract: The records of the Asian/Pacific/American (A/P/A) Institute, dated 1994-2015, document the activities of the Institute and reflect student events, faculty affairs and collaboration with the A/P/A studies program. The collection contains photographs, memoranda, correspondence, student surveys, meeting and conference agendas, syllabi, proposals, posters, flyers, and brochures. It also includes audio cassettes, VHS tapes, and mini DVs.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: These materials transferred to the University Archives in four accessions in 2008, 2009, 2010, and 2011.
Additional accretions were received in 2016, 2017, and 2018; the accession number associated with these transfers are 2016.024, 2016.029, 2017.055, and 2018.031.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Administrative records and unpublished reports of New York University are closed for a period of 20 years from the date of their creation. Access to files spanning multiple years will be opened to researchers based on the date of the most recent materials. Board of Trustees records are closed for 35 years from the date of creation. Materials related to personnel, grievances, job and fellowship searches and applications, and all files that fall under the federal Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) are permanently restricted. Additional restrictions may apply to other materials in this collection. For questions regarding specific restrictions, please contact the University Archives.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by the creator are maintained by New York University. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from New York University Archives, (212) 998-2646, university-archives@nyu.edu.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Published citations should take the following form: Identification of item, date (if known); Records of the Asian/Pacific/American Institute; RG 21.35; box number; folder number; New York University Archives, New York University Libraries.

bioghist.head: History of the Asian/Pacific/American Institute
bioghist.p: The Asian/Pacific/American (A/P/A) Institute was founded in 1996. The Institute is focused on community and intercultural studies within a broad, rigorous international and comparative framework.

The A/P/A Institute produces public events and symposia for the larger New York University and New York City communities. The Institute brings together accomplished scholars, community builders, and artists from New York City and beyond for events throughout the year, including conferences, seminars, book readings, film screenings, musical performances, and brown bag lunches. The Institute also co-sponsors events with student and community organizations, which complement the academic programs offered by the University and address the needs of the community at large.

The A/P/A has collaborated on several events and activities with the Office for African American, Latino, and Asian American Student Services (OASIS). OASIS was created in 1988 in response to the expressed needs of students of color for more University administrative support and commitment. Today the mission of OASIS continues to be carried out by the Center for Multicultural Education and Programs (CMEP) at NYU.

The A/P/A Institute also reached out to youth in New York City through the Asian Pacific American Youth Alliance (APAYA) from 1994-2008. This was a free program led by A/P/A and community volunteers throughout the school year that sought to support and encourage high school youth to become community leaders. These students learned about and taught others about the vibrant and diverse Asian Pacific American history, cultures, and experiences. Their weekly meetings throughout the school year culminated in a forum at NYU planned and led by APAYA students.

list.item: New York University. "Asian/Pacific/American Studies: The Institute." http://www.apa.nyu.edu
New York University. "Center for Multicultural Education and Programs: About Us." http://www.cmep.nyu.edu

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The records of the Asian/Pacific/American (A/P/A) Institute, dated 1994-2015, document the activities of the Institute from its founding in 1996 and reflect student events, faculty affairs and collaboration with the A/P/A studies program. The collection contains photographs, memoranda, correspondence, student surveys, meeting and conference agendas, syllabi, proposals, posters, flyers, and brochures. It also includes audio cassettes, VHS tapes, and mini DVs.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Lesley Espenship in 2008, John Bence and Lindsay Dumas in 2009, Megan Findling in 2012, and Aleksandr Gelfand in 2013.

In October 2016 Craig Savino added Series VIII: 2016 Accretion to reflect a new accretion of materials. Kate Fisher added Series IX : 2017 to reflect a second accretion of materials. These accretions were added to to the resource as accessions and do not reflect the original Records of the Asian/Pacific/American Institute's series arrangement.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Access to audiovisual materials in this collection is available through digitized access copies. Researchers may view an item's original container, but the media themselves are not available for playback because of preservation concerns. Materials that have already been digitized are noted in the collection's finding aid and can be requested in our reading room.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Some personal information in this series has been restricted. Please contact the University Archives for details.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I contains information on the preparation and production of the Asians in America conference from 1994-1998, as well as other conferences of interest to the A/P/A community including Where is Home? Annual Conference for Chinese in the Americas, held in 1997 and Public Displays of Asianness, held in 1998. The records generally pertain to conference logistics, planning, and publicity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II is divided into four subseries that relate to specific A/P/A staff members.

did.unittitle: Subseries A: Sheelagh Cabalda, Office for African American, Latino and Asian American Student Services (OASIS)

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Some of the material within this subseries is restricted because it contains personal information. The physical folders within this collection that are restricted and the boxes have been marked.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries A contains records pertaining to Sheelagh Cabalda's work at the Office for African American, Latino and Asian American Student Services (OASIS) in collaboration with A/P/A. This subseries documents various conferences, workshops and events produced by OASIS, A/P/A and other institutions. These records provide an understanding of student activities and events related to A/P/A Institute.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries B contains correspondence, memoranda, and reports related to the further development of the A/P/A studies academic program. This includes new course proposals, staff and faculty job descriptions, the development of a mission statement, departmental magazines, and the creation of an alumni association. These records reflect the planning involved in the ongoing development of the academic program.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries C includes general course information related to the A/P/A program in addition to various events sponsored by the department. This subseries contains syllabi, course evaluations, course proposals and event records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries D contains syllabi from classes given at A/P/A.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III consists of information regarding various events and activities produced and sponsored by the A/P/A Institute. These records are primarily comprised of outreach materials, such as posters, brochures, and flyers. The majority of these events are art-related, such as gallery exhibitions, author reading series, and film screenings. Events also include lectures and discussions regarding various issues relevant to the A/P/A student community. Many of these events were documented either on film or audio. These recordings are included in the collection. This series is divided into three subseries: a series of general materials organized alphabetically, a series of posters, and a series of general materials organized chronologically. The material in Subseries 3 was received at a later date, and its chronological organization has been retained.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series V contains material on the Asian Pacific American Youth Alliance (APAYA), including program activities, surveys, and material pertaining to planning and logistics.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Since this subseries contains the records of a youth program, some of the material is restricted because it has recent students' personal and contact information. Folders containing such material have been marked.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VII contains a large A/P/A banner.
